CONJUGATES: barricades (n.pl.) | barricades (v. 3rd pers. sing. pres.) | barricading (v. pres. part.) | barricaded (v. past tense & past part.)
ETYMOLOGY: From French barricade (a defensive barrier), from barrique (barrel), because barrels filled with earth were often used to create such barriers.

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: Noun: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A hastily constructed barrier across a street or other thoroughfare, especially one erected by a crowd or rebels to prevent or hinder passage.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: （尤其指由人群或反叛者匆忙搭建的）路障、街垒，用于阻止或阻碍通行。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The protesters set up a barricade to block the main road.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 抗议者设置了路障来封锁主干道。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: Transitive verb: A verb that takes one or more objects.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To block or defend (a place, typically a building or street) with a barricade or similar barrier.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 用障碍物堵塞或防御（某地，通常指建筑物或街道）。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: They barricaded the doors and windows with furniture to prevent entry.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他们用家具堵住了门窗，以阻止进入。

REGISTER: Common usage, often associated with protests, civil unrest, or emergency situations.
